recipeDescriptionLines.recipeDescriptionLine: Paratha originated in Punjab is a popular flatbread which is stuffed with boiled or cooked vegetables like potatoes, methi (fenugreek), cauliflower, radish, paneer etc.

Cabbage Paratha is becoming a known dish in many households now. This dish can be served as breakfast or dinner where cabbage is cooked with spices and later used as a stuffing in wheat flour dough and served hot with raita (yoghurt dip) \ pickles \ curries\ chutneys or simply butter spread on top.
Cabbage is a great source of Vitamin C and fiber.

procedureSteps.stepDescription: Shred cabbage and soak in the water and 1/4 tsp salt for 15 mins. This helps in cleaning the cabage well. Drain the excess water and keep it aside.

In a pan heat oil. Add cumin seeds, allow it to splutter. add ginger and green chillies, saut√© for 30 secs. Add coriander, cumin powder, fry for 30 secs. Add cabbage. Mix it well. Cook uncovered for 2 mins.
Mix remaining dry powders to cabbage. cover and cook for 8-10 mins or till cabbage is cooked completely and all water content is removed. Add salt if required. Allow it to cool.

For making dough, add salt and oil to flour and mix it well. Add half water and knead thoroughly with fingers. Now add little water and knead again. Repeat this step till the right consistency is achieved. If you try to take a portion of dough, it should not stick to your hands. If it does, it  means, there is excess water in the dough. Add little flour and knead again. Keep it aside for 10-15 mins.

Heat a pan on medium flame and put the paratha dough on it. Once you start noticing the raised bumps surface, flip it. Apply little ghee or oil on the flipped surface. Once the other side is cooked, flip it again and apply little ghee or oil. Keep it aside. Repeat the step for remaining dough. Serve hot with raita

tips.tipDesc: It takes practice to make a good dough, so while making dough, add water in little portions. Make sure any kind of stuffing is cool before making parathas.
While rolling parathas after stuffing, you will see bubbles popping. Prick the bubbles using a tooth pick. This will prevent dough layer from breaking.
